./.title: Overview
./.body:
Overview
Tonight we are using schematics from Angular Material and CDK (Component Development Kit) libraries to create an application. We'll show how easy schematics are to use and how to quickly scaffold a basic website. This is a self-directed workshop. We may interrupt work to check progress, if we find any mistakes or encounter new problems, special hints, etc. Please feel free to ask us or your neighbors for assistance.
At the end of this mini-workshop we'll have an application that looks like this. You can check it out for yourself on StackBlitz.

Pre-requisites
For tonight's work, please install the latest version of Angular CLI. You will need a recent version of Node and npm. Install or update Angular CLI by running 
npm i -g @angular/cli

You'll also need an IDE of your choosing.
Hint- collapse the table of contents for worksheet
Click on the hamburger menu () at the top of the page to toggle the table of contents. You can also use the keyboard shortcut s.

Hint- customize font size and color of the worksheet
Click on the font menu () at the top of the page to open a menu where you can make your font larger or smaller or change background color.

1generate.html.title: Generate An App
1generate.html.body:
Generate Angular App

Generate the app using Angular CLI by running
ng new 

Select options to include routing and use SCSS for styles.
 You used your first schematic of the workshop.

Open the new app in your IDE and serve the app using ng serve --o as a refresher of what you get out of the box.

Stop serving the app. The next step changes angular.json and the watcher won't catch changes made in that file.

Let's get Material library in here. Use Angular CLI's add command to run the schematic created by the Material team.
ng add @angular/material

Select options to set your theme color (pick anything except Custom), include hammerjs, and include browser animations.

A lot happened in this schematic. Here's some of the changes made to your app 

added npm packages
updated the angular.json file to include your theme 
imported hammerjs to your main entry files for both the app and for testing 
added browser animations
imported Material icons
added some default styles 

You can read up more about what all happened in Material's Schematic Guide.
Material is an opinionated library. If you don't want all the opinions, you can use the CDK instead (which we will use next, but doesn't have as many control options) or back out some of the changes.


Now let's bring in CDK using the add command again.
ng add @angular/cdk


Running these schematic didn't make any code changes though. You can serve the app again for the remainder of the workshop.

2navigation.html.title: Add Nav View
2navigation.html.body:
Navigation View
We'll create a navigation view for the app using Material's built in schematic to quickly scaffold out a responsive nav list. This schematic is different from the ones we used before-- we'll use CLI's generate command. In addition to generating components or services, the generate command takes a schematic as a param to generate code so that anyone can create and distribute their own schematic. 

Generate the nav view by running the following command. You can pass in any name for the component. We'll use 'navigation' for simplicity.
ng generate @angular/material:nav 

The schematic creates a component and adds it to the AppModule like what you'd expect if you created a component without using a schematic. It also imports Material control dependencies and adds a lot more code to the component than a basic component generation.


To consume this new component, replace all the code in app.component.html with the selector for the nav component.

View your reloaded app. 

Resize your browser window or use your browser's device emulation mode to see how the nav list changes for smaller form factors.

Take a peek at the code for the navigation component. In particular, check out the component.ts and the component.html.

3dashboard.html.title: Add Dashboard
3dashboard.html.body:
Dashboard
Material has a few more schematics we can play with. Let's create a dashboard view as the main view for this app. This schematic uses cards arranged in a grid list.

Generate the dashboard view by running the following command. You can pass in any name for the component. We'll use 'dashboard' for simplicity.
ng generate @angular/material:dashboard 


To consume this new component, find the comment "Add Content Here" in navigation.component.html. Replace the comment with the dashboard component selector.

View your reloaded app. 

Resize your browser window or use your browser's device emulation mode to see how the cards in nav list changes for smaller form factors.

Take a peek at the dashboard component code. Feel free to change card titles or sizes.
